articles.headline: China’s Inflation Hits American Price Tags
articles.snippet: With the prices of Chinese goods sold in the United States starting to rise, the era of ultra-cheap goods may be coming to an end.
articles.abstract: With the prices of Chinese goods sold in the United States starting to rise, the era of ultra-cheap goods may be coming to an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  China’s latest export is inflation. After falling for years, prices of Chinese goods sold in the United States have risen for the last eight months.

articles.headline: Kurds’ Power Wanes as Arab Anger Rises
articles.snippet: Once in a position of strength, Iraqi Kurds are pursuing policies that are uniting most Sunnis and many Shiites.
articles.abstract: Once in a position of strength, Iraqi Kurds are pursuing policies that are uniting most Sunnis and many Shiites.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  As a minority group in Iraq, the Kurds have enjoyed disproportionate influence in the country’s politics since the ouster of Saddam Hussein in 2003. But now their leverage appears to be declining as tensions rise with Iraqi Arabs, raising the specter of another fissure alongside the sectarian divide between Sunnis and Shiites.

articles.headline: A Green Energy Industry Takes Root in California
articles.snippet: Solar power is booming in California, the product of billions of dollars in investment and great enthusiasm.
articles.abstract: Solar power is booming in California, the product of billions of dollars in investment and great enthusiasm.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The sun is starting to grow jobs.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and John Markoff

articles.headline: One on One in Debate, Democrats Set Aim at G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The Democratic rivals did not mask their divisions even as they looked ahead to a fight with the Republican Party.
articles.abstract: The Democratic rivals did not mask their divisions even as they looked ahead to a fight with the Republican Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama met for debate here Thursday, sitting side by side and sharing a night of smiles, friendly eye-catching and gentle banter. Cordial as the encounter was, the candidates did not mask their own divisions, even as they previewed the attacks one of them will ultimately make against a Republican rival.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Coins in the New Realm
articles.snippet: The notion that names of Web sites can be valuable, cash-generating assets just like stocks, bonds or property appears to be gaining a broader acceptance.
articles.abstract: The notion that names of Web sites can be valuable, cash-generating assets just like stocks, bonds or property appears to be gaining a broader acceptance.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD  Xavier Buck planned to spend $100,000 to bid for domain names, those parcels of virtual Internet real estate, at a live auction here last week.

articles.headline: Ad Growth Still Strong, Google Says
articles.snippet: Google reported a 17 percent jump in profit and a 51 percent growth in revenue in the fourth quarter, falling shy of Wall Street’s expectations.
articles.abstract: Google reported a 17 percent jump in profit and a 51 percent growth in revenue in the fourth quarter, falling shy of Wall Street’s expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Google said it has seen no effect from a slowing economy on its advertising business, as it reported a 17 percent jump in profit and a 51 percent growth in revenue in the fourth quarter.

articles.headline: Giuliani Will Return Diminished, but Not Finished, Associates Say
articles.snippet: He left as America’s Mayor. But Rudolph W. Giuliani will return to New York’s business and political arenas as a mere mortal.
articles.abstract: He left as America’s Mayor. But Rudolph W. Giuliani will return to New York’s business and political arenas as a mere mortal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  He left as America’s Mayor. But Rudolph W. Giuliani will return to New York’s business and political arenas as a mere mortal, some of his friends and business associates acknowledge.

articles.headline: Women Weigh Use of Clout in Primary
articles.snippet: Women are a crucial vote in the primary in New York, where they represent 55 percent of registered Democrats statewide and 60 percent in the city.
articles.abstract: Women are a crucial vote in the primary in New York, where they represent 55 percent of registered Democrats statewide and 60 percent in the city.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the garden-level kitchen of a Harlem brownstone last Sunday, five women sat around a long wooden table, overshadowed by a large leafy plant in the window, sipping hazelnut coffee and excitedly finishing one another’s sentences as they talked about the presidential candidates as if they were on intimate terms, calling them Hillary and Barack.

articles.headline: Stocks Rally in Defiance of Bad News
articles.snippet: Wall Street was sharply higher as investors shrugged off concerns about problems in the bond insurance industry.
articles.abstract: Wall Street was sharply higher as investors shrugged off concerns about problems in the bond insurance industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thursday had all the ingredients for a bearish day on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Like Home-Builder Shares? Look Again
articles.snippet: The worse the news got, the better the stocks performed.
articles.abstract: The worse the news got, the better the stocks performed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The worse the news got, the better the stocks performed.

articles.headline: McCain’s Critics on Right Look Again
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain has long aroused opposition from conservatives. Now, some see him in a new light.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain has long aroused opposition from conservatives. Now, some see him in a new light.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain has long aroused almost unanimous opposition from the leaders of the right. Accusing him of crimes against conservative orthodoxy like voting against a big tax cut and opposing a federal ban on same-sex marriage, conservative activists have agitated for months to thwart his Republican presidential primary campaign.
